attributes.title: The Gendered Politics of Congressional Elections

q1.value: The Gendered Politics of Congressional Elections

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: In our recent paper, “The Gendered Politics of Congressional Elections” (under review), we evaluate the effect of candidate gender on vote-choice and election outcomes. Our paper builds upon and extends the previous research by incorporating a larger set of congressional races, over a longer time period. Unlike previous research, we study all 435 congressional districts across a 10-year period. We show that women are as successful as men at attracting votes when they are more qualified, but when qualifications are held constant, women receive fewer votes and are more likely to lose. We run a logit model of the probability of winning in 2016, controlling for the candidate’s gender and partisanship, spending, relative experience and district-level characteristics (e.g., median income, percent college educated, percent minority, etc.). We store the coefficients, and then generate the predicted probability of winning in 2018 using information about candidate characteristics in 2018 (e.g., candidate gender and partisanship, spending, relative experience). We predict modest gains for women Democrats and a net loss for female Republicans. Overall, our predictions are pessimistic about the prospects of a “Pink Wave.” These findings have important implications for our understanding of the macro-level factors that shape women’s electoral fortunes; and advance the democratic norm of representational equality, by helping candidates and campaigns to identify and concentrate their efforts on the most winnable districts.

q16.value: We are interested in predicting the outcome of U.S. House of Representative races in the 2018 elections in which at least one woman is running. So the quantity of interest to be estimated is the probability of winning.

q17.value: We will estimate each candidate’s probability of winning via a logit model with robust standard errors.

registration_responses.q1: The Gendered Politics of Congressional Elections
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q2.value: Megan A. Stewart | Todd S. Sechser

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: What are the social consequences of inequitable resource distribution? Does the uneven allocation of desirable goods impact group cohesion? A public goods game typically measures contributions by everyone to a public account. This account is then divided equally and everyone receives the same payoff. Contributions to a public goods aim to measure a willingness to forgo personal cost-benefit considerations in order to maximize social welfare: the more people contribute, the better everyone's social welfare will be. Social welfare benefits, however, are not always distributed equally. Even supposedly pure public goods, like justice or security, are not distributed equally to all members of the public as a whole. What then are the consequences of this inequitable distribution?

q16.value: In this experiment, we test two rival sets of explanations that may explain contributions to public goods: rationalist explanations and bonding explanations. Rationalist explanations suggest that self-interest should drive contributions to a social welfare maximizing good, regardless of distributional outcomes, while bonding explanations suggest that shared but differential experiences between players create distinct identities and patterns of behavior.

q17.value: We use a multi-stage modified public goods game with aysmmetric payoffs to test our hypotheses.

registration_responses.q2: Megan A. Stewart | Todd S. Sechser

attributes.title: Motivating Waste Reduction and Recycling in the University Workplace: An Experimental Evaluation of Negatively-framed Collective Incentives

q1.value: Motivating Waste Reduction and Recycling in the University Workplace: An Experimental Evaluation of Negatively-framed Collective Incentives

q2.value: Richard M. Walker | Ivan P. Lee | Nicolai Petrovsky | Janet WU

q5.value: This project is funded by Campus Sustainability Fund (CSF) under the Office of the Provost, City University of Hong Kong

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Research suggests that behavioral interventions, such as providing incentives, could promote waste reduction and recycling in the residential sector. However, substantially less attempt has been made to investigate whether the positive results can be extended to organizational settings. Based on a cluster-randomized field experiment, this project examines the effectiveness of a group-based intervention—namely, negatively-framed collective incentive—in motivating waste reduction and paper recycling in the university workplace. Surveys are administered before and after intervention to explore the psychological treatment effects on employees. A total of 24 offices (173 employees) of academic departments and administrative units of a public university in Hong Kong (i.e., City University of Hong Kong, CityU) are involved in the study. The research findings will demonstrate ways waste reduction and other environmental improvements at workplace can be facilitated. It will better inform the implementation of waste charging policy in organizational settings.

q16.value: H1a: Offices assigned to the treatment group ‒ where a negatively framed collective incentive is provided‒ would produce less waste and recycle more paper relative to the baseline level than offices assigned to the control group. H1b: When the treatment is withdrawn, the amount of waste generated and paper recycled in the offices of the treatment group will return to the baseline level. H2: Employees assigned to the treatment group would have a higher level of self-reported paper recycling behavior relative to the pretest measurement than employees assigned to the control group. H3: Employees assigned to the treatment group would have a higher level of behavioral intention to recycle paper relative to the pretest measurement than employees assigned to the control group. H4: Employees assigned to the treatment group would have a more positive attitude towards paper recycling relative to the pretest measurement than employees assigned to the control group. H5: Employees assigned to the treatment group would have a more positive attitude towards the recycling performance of CityU relative to the pretest measurement than employees assigned to the control group. H6: Employees assigned to the treatment group would have a lower level of personal norms towards paper recycling relative to the pretest measurement than employees assigned to the control group.

q17.value: Experimental Design A cluster-randomized field experiment with a control group A-B-A (Baseline-Treatment-Withdrawal) design is carried out at CityU. The baseline period lasts for 3 weeks, the treatment period lasts for 4 weeks, and the withdrawal period lasts for 2 weeks. A total of 24 offices (173 employees) of academic departments and administrative units are involved in the study. 11 offices (74 employees) are randomly assigned to the treatment group. An online survey questionnaire is distributed to all subjects before and after the experiment. Major dependent variable The amount of waste generated and paper recycled in the offices. These amounts are weighed by student interns twice a week. Others dependent variables The employees’ self-reported behavior, behavioral intention, attitude, personal norms towards paper recycling, as well as their attitude towards CityU’s recycling performance. These variables are measured by the online survey administrated before and after the experiment. Treatment Negatively-framed collective incentive. The employees assigned to the treatment group are informed that: • Their office is randomly selected to be involved in a waste-charging pilot scheme. • A “Green Account” has been created for their office and HKD $1400 has been deposited into the account. • For each lb of waste their office generates, HKD $15 will be deducted from the “Green Account”. • The balance of their “Green Account” cannot fall below $0. • Recycling paper will not be charged. • After the treatment period, the remaining amount in their “Green Account” will be used to purchase coupons/snacks to reward their waste reduction efforts.

q21.value: A power analysis is conducted, but the actual sample size cannot achieve the expected level due to practical constraints

q23.value: This project is approved by the Office of the Provost, City University of Hong Kong

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This is an exploratory study to answer the following question: What government language does the public interpret as moral? The study will test whether and how moral preferences and foreign policy orientations influence respondent evaluations of government rhetoric as moral. The goal of the study is to select two moral statements and two nonmoral statements to include in a vignette-style survey experiment examining the impact of moral rhetoric on opinions toward a hypothetical military intervention.

q16.value: I code each Presidential statement according to which morals I expect the speech to tap into (see pre-analysis plan). I expect subjects who score highly on those foundations to rate the statement as more moral than those who score low. These are rough predictions, used only to guide the choice of speeches. Actual respondent coding will determine the use of and categorization of each speech.

q17.value: First, I will replicate Kertzer et al.'s findings regarding the relationship between moral foundations and foreign policy orientation. Second, I will estimate the impact of the six moral foundations and the foreign policy orientations on the four measures of morality using standard regression. Finally, I will also conduct exploratory analysis of the relationship among the various demographic and political identification variables with the moral foundations, foreign policy orientations, and reactions to rhetoric.

q5.value: We thank Yusaku Horiuchi and Sean Westwood for helpful advice.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Selective exposure occurs when people seek out news content that reinforces their existing preferences. In the contemporary media environment, a common source of selective exposure is partisanship. For instance, Republicans often prefer to watch FOX or read the Wall Street Journal while Democrats often prefer to watch MSNBC or read the New York Times (Levendusky 2013, Stroud 2011). Partisan selective exposure may exacerbate polarization (Stroud 2010) and lead members of opposite parties to hold different beliefs about political facts (Shapiro and Bloch-Elkon 2008). In this project, we measure the extent of partisan selective exposure and investigate one potential strategy for reducing it. Specifically, we investigate whether information from non-partisan fact-checking organizations about the factual accuracy of news content mitigates partisan selective exposure. To test this hypothesis, we conduct a randomized conjoint experiment on Amazon.com’s Mechanical Turk (MTurk).

q16.value: H1a: Participants will be more likely to select articles that fact-checkers have found to be accurate compared to articles that have not been fact-checked. H1b: Participants will be less likely to select articles that fact-checkers have found to be inaccurate compared to articles that have not been fact-checked. H2: Partisans will be more (less) likely to select articles from co-partisan (out-partisan) sources compared to non-partisan sources. H3: Negative fact-checker ratings will decrease partisan selective exposure. RQ1: Are strong partisans more likely to engage in partisan selective exposure (compared to weak partisans and independent leaners)? RQ2: Are participants who are high in political knowledge and political interest more likely to engage in partisan selective exposure (compared to participants low in knowledge and interest, respectively)?

q17.value: Respondents and data collection Participants will be recruited from MTurk (Berinsky et al. 2012). We will recruit approximately 1,700 participants (the maximum allowable under the study budget). Dates of administration March 7-14, 2017 Eligibility and exclusion criteria for participants Any adult who has an MTurk “worker” account, resides in the United States, and has a past HIT approval rate of 95% or higher is eligible. Primary and secondary outcome measures Following the traditional conjoint design, participants will be presented with a series of tables that contain information on two alternatives and then asked to choose one of these alternatives. For us, the alternatives are two news articles (i.e., our outcome of interest is which article participants prefer to read). Each table will have 5 rows and 3 columns. The rows contain information on our two alternatives. Columns will be labeled “Article A” and “Article B,” and rows will be labeled as follows: -Article headline and description: -Source: -Fact-checker rating of article (if available): -Published: In the parlance of conjoint analysis, the independent variables of interest are “attributes” and their possible values are “levels” (see Hainmueller et al. 2013). The following table gives all possible values of each attribute. [TABLE AVAILABLE IN ATTACHED PDF] Additional information on conjoint design and coding: -Attributes will be fully randomized (i.e., no restrictions will be imposed in order to rule out certain combinations of attributes) -The order in which attributes appear in the conjoint table will be fixed in the order displayed in the table above: headline/description, source, fact-checker rating, days since published. (This reflects the order in which these data are typically displayed when searching for news articles online.) -All participants will be presented with 10 conjoint tasks (i.e., tables). Thus, each participant can make a maximum of 10 selections. -For testing our selective exposure hypotheses, we will code source partisanship as follows: *pro-Republican: Fox News, Breitbart *pro-Democratic: MSNBC, Huffington Post *neutral/non-partisan: Associated Press, Newsday -Note that we also include the New York Times and Wall Street Journal as sources. While these sources have ideological reputations, they are arguably less overtly partisan than the other sources we use. Thus, we do not consider the New York Times or Wall Street Journal in our main analyses. We may report additional results using these two sources in an appendix to assess robustness. -For testing the fact-checker hypotheses, we will merge all star-level ratings into a single category (e.g., 1 star ratings from PolitiFact, FactCheck.org, and WashingtonPost Fact-Checker will be treated as a single attribute). We may report additional results treating ratings from different fact-checkers as separate attributes in an appendix to assess robustness. Statistical analyses We will use the “cjoint” package (Strezhnev et al. 2016) in R to estimate Average Marginal Component Effects and Average Component Interaction Effects. See Hainmueller et al. 2013 for a discussion of these two estimands. H1a: Participants will be more likely to select articles that fact-checkers have found to be accurate compared to articles that have not been fact-checked. H1b: Participants will be less likely to select articles that fact-checkers have found to be inaccurate compared to articles that have not been fact-checked. We will estimate AMCEs for all 5 levels of fact-checker rating (no fact-check information will be the omitted baseline group). H2: Partisans will be more (less) likely to select articles from co-partisan (out-partisan) sources compared to non-partisan sources. As discussed above, we will code news sources as pro-Democratic, pro-Republican, or non-partisan. We will then use participants’ self-reported partisanship to recode each source as co-partisan, out-partisan, or neutral (leaners will be treated as partisans and pure independents will be excluded from this test). We will estimate AMCEs for co-partisan and out-partisan source (neutral will be the omitted baseline). H3: Negative fact-checker ratings will decrease partisan selective exposure. We will interact the two attributes of interest—partisanship of source and fact-checker rating—and report ACIEs. RQ1: Are strong partisans more likely to engage in partisan selective exposure (compared to weak partisans and independent leaners)? We will re-run the test of H2 on the subsample of strong partisans and report whether the AMCE associated with source is larger for strong partisans compared to weak partisans. RQ2: Are participants who are high in political knowledge and political interest more likely to engage in partisan selective exposure (compared to participants low in knowledge and interest, respectively)? We will re-run the test of H2 on the subsample of high knowledge participants and report whether the AMCE associated with source is larger for high knowledge participants compared to low knowledge participants. Similarly, we will re-run the test of H2 on the subsample of highly politically interested participants and report whether the AMCE associated with source is larger for high interest participants compared to low interest participants. (For both knowledge and interest, we will divide the sample into high and low by dichotomizing at the empirical median.) Notes: -We will compute and report appropriate auxiliary quantities from our models, including AMCEs and ACIEs by subgroups. -”Don’t know” responses will be considered as missing data. -We will also compute and report summary statistics for our sample. We will also collect and may report response timing data as a proxy for respondent attention. -The order of hypotheses and analyses in the final manuscript may be altered for expositional clarity. -We reserve the right to present our results graphically and report AMCEs and ACIEs in an appendix.

attributes.title: Do museums promote reconciliation? A field experiment in Santiago, Chile

q1.value: Do museums promote reconciliation? A field experiment in Santiago, Chile

q2.value: Laia Balcells | Valeria Palanza | Elsa Voytas

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: In recent years, it has become increasingly common to commemorate victims of conflict and crimes against humanity with museums and memorial sites that recount the offenses they faced. The prevalence of such sites therefore generates numerous questions: how do they impact visitors and observers? Does their existence promote societal reconciliation? Do museums and memorials alter citizens’ current political preferences? Memorial and museum establishment typically rests on the implicit assumption that they will encourage social cohesion and national unity. To test this assumption, we conduct a randomized field experiment in Santiago, Chile. We evaluate the impact of visiting the Museo de la Memoria y los Derechos Humanos (Museum of Memory and Human Rights), a state-established memorial museum commemorating the victims of the Pinochet military dictatorship. By measuring changes in individual attitudes after being randomly assigned to visit the museum, our findings seek to advance advance our understanding of the effects of museums and memorials addressing a society’s sensitive history.

q16.value: Visiting a transitional justice museum will harm perceptions of intergroup relations. Visiting a transitional justice museum will cause visitors to reject the political institutions associated with the military dictatorship. Visiting a transitional justice museum will entrench existing political views. Visiting a transitional justice museum will increase support for transitional justice policies. Visiting a transitional justice museum will increase individuals' awareness of current inequalities and injustices. We expect that the effects will be larger if someone has a close relationship to a victim. Though we expect that individuals' pre-treatment ideology will become stronger after treatment regardless of ideology, we expect the results to be stronger among those on the right. We expect the results to be weaker among those who score highly on the right-wing authoritarianism scale. We expect that the results will be smaller for those who discussed the dictatorship often at home as well as those who indicate that they are quite interested in politics. Being reminded of victims and one's relationship to victims will decrease one's willingness to say that human rights violations were justified.

q17.value: Subjects will be randomly assigned to visit the Museo de la Memoria y los Derechos Humanos in Santiago, Chile.

registration_responses.q1: Do museums promote reconciliation? A field experiment in Santiago, Chile
registration_responses.q2: Laia Balcells | Valeria Palanza | Elsa Voytas
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment
registration_responses.q15: In recent years, it has become increasingly common to commemorate victims of conflict and crimes against humanity with museums and memorial sites that recount the offenses they faced. The prevalence of such sites therefore generates numerous questions: how do they impact visitors and observers? Does their existence promote societal reconciliation? Do museums and memorials alter citizens’ current political preferences? Memorial and museum establishment typically rests on the implicit assumption that they will encourage social cohesion and national unity. To test this assumption, we conduct a randomized field experiment in Santiago, Chile. We evaluate the impact of visiting the Museo de la Memoria y los Derechos Humanos (Museum of Memory and Human Rights), a state-established memorial museum commemorating the victims of the Pinochet military dictatorship. By measuring changes in individual attitudes after being randomly assigned to visit the museum, our findings seek to advance advance our understanding of the effects of museums and memorials addressing a society’s sensitive history.
registration_responses.q16: Visiting a transitional justice museum will harm perceptions of intergroup relations. Visiting a transitional justice museum will cause visitors to reject the political institutions associated with the military dictatorship. Visiting a transitional justice museum will entrench existing political views. Visiting a transitional justice museum will increase support for transitional justice policies. Visiting a transitional justice museum will increase individuals' awareness of current inequalities and injustices. We expect that the effects will be larger if someone has a close relationship to a victim. Though we expect that individuals' pre-treatment ideology will become stronger after treatment regardless of ideology, we expect the results to be stronger among those on the right. We expect the results to be weaker among those who score highly on the right-wing authoritarianism scale. We expect that the results will be smaller for those who discussed the dictatorship often at home as well as those who indicate that they are quite interested in politics. Being reminded of victims and one's relationship to victims will decrease one's willingness to say that human rights violations were justified.
registration_responses.q17: Subjects will be randomly assigned to visit the Museo de la Memoria y los Derechos Humanos in Santiago, Chile.

attributes.title: Social heuristics as a tool for political member generating - A field experiment in the Danish Consumer Council

q1.value: Social heuristics as a tool for political member generating - A field experiment in the Danish Consumer Council

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: The background for my master thesis is twofold. First of all I'm interested in the aspect of political behaviour, which examine political participation. From a societal perspective it is very interesting that the political participation in the western countries is graduately changing. Putnam (2000) arguments that the decline in turnout is associated with a generel trend in which people are bowling alone due to lack of social capital. This decline in social capital has changed the way people participate in politics, not only in decreasing turnout but also a huge decrease in memberships of political parties and non-governmental organisations. The second background for my master thesis is much more scientific. It is a known fact that politics is all about humans, and that it is humans who make the political decisions. It is therefore difficult to study politics without knowing how humans make those decisions cognitively. My argument is that it is centrally for political scientist to use psychological tools to better understand and analyse human behavior. My rationale is therefore in this thesis to examine how one can use psychological heuristics to influence political decision making and increase political participation

q16.value: 1. When faced with an e-mail, in which focus is on doing the same as other people, people generally tends to participate in the panel, than if the e-mail are focused on motivation thru information enlightening about how important the participation is for other people. 2. The respondents which already is a member of the panel will generally be more willing to participate in the survey when presented with social heuristics than people who is not a member. In concrete terms I expect the average treatment effect is bigger in the experiment with current members of the panel than the experiment with people who is neither a panel member or a member of the organization.

q17.value: They will be tested with to field-experiments in cooperation with the danish NGO Danish Consumer Council and the first hypothesis will be tested with a difference of means estimation in experiment-effect in the two experiments (four groups). The second experiment will be tested with a two sided t-test to examine if the two ATE's in the two experiments are different from one another.

q19.value: Unknown for now: I expect approximately 1.000 units in each group (4.000 in total)

attributes.title: The Effect of Projections of Racial Composition in the United States

q1.value: The Effect of Projections of Racial Composition in the United States

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: We predict that a large source of the angst about immigration is the perceived loss of majority status by whites, which was enflamed by flawed Census projections. These projections that whites will be a minority in the United States by 2044 are wrong for three important reasons. Whites will remain a majority for the foreseeable future due to a recent rapid decline in immigration, the majority of Hispanics viewing themselves as whites, and the large percentage of interracial children who consider themselves white and marry whites. All of these were miscalculated by the Census projections. These results will show that technocratic influence on public opinion is not necessarily as benign as many in democratic theorists suggest, due to the typical difficulties of social scientific forecasting.

q16.value: We will test the impact of these incorrect technocratic claims on public opinion in a survey experiment on a nationally-representative sample. We believe that that whites who read that whites will become the minority report feeling bad, have a less hope for America’s future, are more likely to support deportation for immigrants and feel less connected to their American identity. We also think that whites with higher Social Dominance Orientation will be even more likely to report feeling bad, have a less hope for America’s future, are more likely to support deportation for immigrants and feel less connected to their American identity.
